page.title: 01Struan & Calvine
page.content: This area can be divided into three. One section is private conifer woodland. One is arable land close to Garry but not suitable for large acreages of grain, this is mostly grassland used for hay silage and grazing. The third section rises to heather clad moorland, here in bad weather up to 1,000 deer can be seen. The main employment is agriculture with the hardy blackface ewe being the biggest farm enterprise. This is Robertson country with their own museum at Bruar site of the annual gathering glimpses of General Wade's road can still be seen as well as a stone of sacrifice at Bruar, Clach an Iobairt. At Struan trains start their steep ascent through Gelen Garry to the Dunmochester summit 1507ft.
